title: Article_Title
content: One-step in-situ synthesis of porous Fe3+-doped TiO2 octahedra toward visible-light photocatalytic conversion of CO2 into solar fuel

title: Abstract
content: Here, hollow Fe 3 doped TiO 2 (Fe-TiO 2 ) octahedra were obtained via one-step hydrothermal method with MIL-101(Fe) as the template as well as the iron ion source.By introducing Ti precursor onto MIL-101(Fe) followed by HF etching and hydrothermal treatment, Fe-doped TiO 2 with high porosity and hollow structure was obtained.The as-synthesized Fe-TiO 2 octahedra consist of numerous small nanoparticles with particle sizes between 10 and 20 nm and possess a high specific surface area of 275 m 2 g -1 together with uniform mesopores of 3.7 nm in pore diameter.After heat treatment in air at 500 C (named Fe-TiO 2 -500), the BET surface area and the mesopore size of the sample were changed to 202 m 2 g -1 and 3.9 nm, respectively.Compared to other Fe-doping methods, this method reported here favors better and more uniform Fe doping into the TiO 2 lattice and improves the porosity and specific surface area.As a result of the Fe doping, the bandgaps of Fe-TiO 2 and Fe-TiO 2 -500 were about 2.75 eV and 2.42 eV, respectively.Fe-TiO 2 -500 shows excellent photocatalytic activity due to its special structure, high BET surface area and porosity.The yield of CH 4 is about 7.73 mol g -1 after loading of Pt within 12 h of reaction time under visible light illumination ( 420 nm).

title: Experimental
content: Synthesis of MIL-101(Fe): FeCl 3 6H 2 O (0.5 g) and terephthalic acid (0.15 g) were dissolved in DMF (12 mL).The resulting suspension was dispersed by ultrasound, then moved to a Teflon autoclave liner, and heated at 130 C for 24 h.The products were collected by centrifugation at 10,000 rpm for 2 min, washed with DMF and ethanol three times.Finally, the synthesized MIL-101(Fe) was dried overnight at 60 C. Synthesis of Fe-TiO 2 , Fe-TiO 2 -500 and pure TiO 2 : MIL-101(Fe) (5.0 mg) was dissolved in ethanol (10 mL), followed by adding tetrabutyl titanate (50 L) into the solution.The mixture was dispersed homogeneously by magnetic stirring for 20 min.Subsequently, 700 L of deionized water and 20 L of HF were mixed with constantly stirring for 10 min.Finally, it was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated for 20 h at 180 C. The sample was separated from the solution by centrifugation and washed with deionized water and absolute ethanol repeatedly, then dried under vacuum at 60 C for 24 h.The obtained powder was named as Fe-TiO 2 .In order to remove residual MIL-101 and organic solvents before the CO 2 reduction cycle starts, Fe-TiO 2 was calcined at 500 C in air atmosphere for 6 h, the resultant product was named as Fe-TiO 2 -500.The synthesis of pure TiO nanoparticles is very similar to that of Fe-TiO 2 , except the remove of MIL-101(Fe) (5.0 mg).

title: Results_and_Discussion
content: Scheme 1 illustrates the typical synthesis process of Fe-TiO 2 and Fe-TiO 2 -500 octahedra.Firstly, MIL-101(Fe) octahedra were prepared by a solvothermal method.Then, MIL-101(Fe) octahedra were treated with HF and tetrabutyl titanate to form Fe-TiO 2 .In order to remove the residual MIL-101(Fe), Fe-TiO 2 was calcined in air at 500 C for 6 h, and got the Fe-TiO 2 -500 sample.The hydrothermal reaction of tetrabutyl titanate and HF aqueous solution without MIL-101 resulted in pure TiO particles (Fig. S1 and Fig. 1).The XRD patterns of Fe-TiO 2 and Fe-TiO 2 -500 are similar, only slightly increasing in intensity.The characteristic peaks associated with iron-related phase were not observed.A specific comparison of the (101) diffraction peak in the range of 24 -27 shifted slightly toward a higher 2 value after calcination (Fig. 1b), indicating that more Ti 4 ions of Fe-TiO 2 have been replaced by Fe 3 .Fig. 1c displays the Raman spectra of these samples.The Raman spectrum of TiO 2, Fe-TiO 2 and Fe-TiO 2 -500 are very similar, there are four peaks at 144.8, 396.3, 513.2 and 636.7 cm -1 in low frequency region, which are characteristic of anatase phase TiO 2 .The characteristic peaks corresponding to MIL-101 (Fe) precursor or carbon were not observed in Fe-TiO 2 and Fe-TiO 2 -500 samples, thus confirming that there was no carbon or MIL-101(Fe) in the Scheme 1. Fig. 2 shows the morphology of prepared MIL-101 and Fe-TiO 2 samples.The as-obtained MIL-101 precursor shows well-defined octahedral morphology with smooth surface and an average particle size of 300-500 nm (Fig. 2a and Fig. S2).SEM image of Fe-TiO 2 sample (Fig. 2b) reveals that the octahedral shape of the MIL-101 precursor is well retained, and octahedra particle size increase to 1-2 m.The surface of Fe-TiO 2 becomes rougher (Fig. 2c), which can provide more active sites for the subsequent photocatalytic reaction and enhance its photocatalytic property.A high magnification SEM image of a single Fe-TiO 2 octahedron (the inset of Fig. 2c) reveals that each octahedron was composed of nanoparticles, which provides TiO 2 photocatalyst with a large specific surface area.After annealing at 500 C in air, there was no apparent change in the morphology and the size of octahedra (Fig. 2d), indicating the high stability of Fe-TiO 2 . Further microstructure and morphology analysis of the as-prepared Fe-TiO 2 was performed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM), as shown in Fig. 3. Fe-TiO 2 sample appears as rhombic or cubic in shape by TEM observation of octahedral structure (Fig. 3a andb).A closer examination of the Fe-TiO 2 octahedra shows obvious contrast between the dark edges and the bright center, which demonstrates the hollow texture of Fe-TiO 2 octahedra.The inset of Fig. 3b shows the corresponding selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of a Fe-TiO 2 octahedron, which indicates the polycrystalline nature of octahedra.Each Fe-TiO 2 octahedron is composed of numerous small nanoparticles with a size of 10-20 nm (Fig. 3c).The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image clearly shows lattice fringes with an interplanar distance of ca.0.356 nm, corresponding to the (101) planes of anatase TiO 2 , as shown in the inset of Fig. 3c.The elemental mapping by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) indicates the uniform distribution of Ti, O and Fe species in the Fe-TiO sample (Fig. 3d-g).The contents of Fe, Ti and O are determined to be 6.8, 32.0 and 61.2 wt, respectively.The atomic ratio of Ti and O elements is found to be 1.9, which is close to the theoretical atomic ratio of TiO 2 .The Fe element comes from MIL-101(Fe) precursor.An interesting observation is that there are no TiO 2 deposition in solution when adding It's obvious that the peak of TiO 2 at 403.12 cm -1 is caused by Ti-O-Ti stretching vibration 37.MIL-101(Fe) has two main peaks at 1387.37 cm -1 and 1603.86 cm -1 which are caused by asymmetric and symmetric vibration of COO -ion in MIL-101(Fe) are consistent with those reported in the literature 38.The FT-IR spectra of Fe-TiO 2 octahedrons is similar to TiO 2 and there is no MIL-101(Fe) peaks, suggesting that MIL-101(Fe) no longer exists.In addition, the peaks at 1638.65 cm - and 3451.80 cm -1 , which should be assigned to the bending and stretching vibrations of the adsorbed water molecules 39.The TG and FT-IR results indicate that there are no MIL-101(Fe) in the prepared Fe-TiO 2 .Vibrations of Fig. 5 shows the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm and the pore-size distribution (inset) of Fe-TiO 2 and Fe-TiO 2 -500.The two samples exhibit type H3 hysteresis loops according to the Brunauer-Deming-Deming-Teller (BDDT) classification, implying the presence of mesoporous structures.According to the BET method, the specific surface areas of Fe-TiO 2 and Fe-TiO 2 -500 are and 202 m 2 g -1 , respectively, which is much higher than that of prepared pure TiO 2 (43 m 2 g -1 ).Their pore size distribution was calculated using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, which is about 3.7 nm for Fe-TiO 2 and 3.9 nm for Fe-TiO 2 -500, respectively.The volatilization of the adsorbed organic solvent and decomposition of residual MIL-101 (Fe) by calcination lead to the increase of pore size.The decrease of BET surface areas of Fe-TiO 2 -500 was attributed to the crystal growth of TiO 2 nanoparticles and the increase of pore size under high temperature treatment. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis demonstrates the presence of Ti, O, and Fe in the synthesized Fe-TiO 2 octahedra (Fig. 6a).Ti 2p peaks appeared at about 458.5 eV and 464.2 eV (Fig. 6b), which is the characteristic signal of the Ti 2p 3/2 and Ti 2p 1/2 for TiO 2 , respectively.The two main peaks for Fe at about 711.3 eV and 725.0 eV are belong to Fe 2p 3/2 and Fe 2p 1/2 of Fe 3 ion (Fig. 6c).Compared to the Fe 2 O 3 (710.7eVfor Fe 2p 3/2 ), a slight shift of the Fe 2p toward higher binding energies was observed in the case of Fe-TiO 2 , which indicates that some Fe 3 replace Ti 4 of the TiO 2 to form Fe-O-Ti bonds 40.In addition, there are two peaks at 719.6 eV and 733.6 eV, which are the satellite structure of Fe 3 41.The O 1s XPS spectra can be deconvoluted into two main peaks (Fig. 6d).The peak centered at 529.8 eV could be attributed to the lattice oxygen for TiO 2 42.Another O 1s peak at 531.4 eV belongs likely to the chemisorbed oxygen (i.e., OH, H 2 O) in the surface groups 43.The atom Fe, Ti and O contents of on the surface of octahedra were calculated to be 7.0, 30.9 and 62.1 wt , respectively, which is very similar to the EDS results.Fig. 7 shows UV-Vis spectral of all samples.The absorption threshold of the MIL-101(Fe) is located at about 600 nm.The Fe-TiO 2 octahedra have a great enhancement in the light absorption at wavelengths of 400-600 nm compared to that of the pure anatase TiO 2 .Heat treatment leads to a red shift of the absorption edge.The optical band gap energy of the pure TiO 2 , MIL-101(Fe), Fe-TiO 2 and Fe-TiO 2 -500 are about 3.3 eV, 2.80 eV, 2.75 eV and 2.42 eV calculated from the intercept of the tangents to the plots (Fig. 7b).When Fe is doped into TiO 2 , the band gap of TiO 2 is decreased.The color of pure TiO 2 is white whereas Fe-TiO 2 is yellow.The smaller band gap indicates the stronger response to visible light, thus Fe-TiO 2 octahedrons with excellent photocatalytic activity are expected. Using photoreduction 44, electrochemical reduction 45 or methanation 46 to convert CO 2 into valuable fuels provides a hopeful method to alleviate global energy crisis and environmental issues.In this paper, the prepared Fe-TiO 2 octahedrons were applied for the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with water.The photoreduction experiments were performed in a gas solid system containing water and CO 2 under visible-light ( 420 nm).Fig. 8a displays that the Fe-TiO 2 octahedrons 8c.The strongest peak of both samples appears at g 1.99, which can be attributed to Fe 3 substituted for Ti 4 in the TiO 2 lattice 48.This result confirms that Fe 3 ions are successfully doped into the TiO 2 lattice.The above EPR signal is enhanced obviously after 500 C heat treatment, which is due to more Fe 3 ions were incorporated into TiO 2 lattice after heat treatment.The photoluminescence (PL) spectra are presented in Fig. 8d to provide additional evidence for improving charge carriers transport.Compared to Fe-TiO 2 , a slight decrease in PL intensity can be observed in Fe-TiO 2 -500, suggested the longer lifetime of photo-generated charge carriers compared to Fe-TiO 2 . title: Conclusions
content: In summary, Fe 3 doped TiO 2 (Fe-TiO 2 ) octahedra were successfully prepared by a one-step hydrothermal method, using MIL-101(Fe) both as the template and the iron ion source.The formation of TiO 2 and the etching of MIL-101(Fe) occur simultaneously driven by fluorine ion.The obtained Fe-TiO 2 show uniformly Fe doping with a high specific surface area before and after the heat treatment (Fe-TiO 2 : 274 m 2 g -1 , Fe-TiO 2 -500:202 m 2 g -1 ).At last, the Fe-TiO 2 -500 octahedra show excellent photocatalytic activity, and the yield of CH 4 is about 7.73 mol g -1 after loading of Pt within 12 h of reaction time under visible light illumination.This work provides a convenient way for designing and preparing novel mental doped nanomaterials with high photocatalytic properties.
